content.description:
The 4-5 inch wide crack splitting the southwest face of Chimney Rock is an old-school blue-collar thrutch and a great example of 5.9 offwidth from the 1970s. 

  The most direct line from the ground climbs a chossy stembox to reach the first major ledge. Walk to the back of the ledge and enter the chimney - you have the option of taking a finger crack (left) or heaving over a large chockstone in the chimney (right). You can get a #3 cam below the first roof before things get wide. Longsleeves and tenacity highly recommended. 

  Just below the summit there are many options for a gear belay. Rappel (70m rope) from chains down southwest face.
content.protection: Doubles: 4 and 5 c4 camalot   Singles: .5 to 3 c4 camalot (mostly for gear anchor)   Couple TCUs if taking the finger crack
content.location: Obvious 4-inch offwidth splitting the southwest face of Chimney Rock. Approach via Chimney Rock Trail. 15-20 minutes

climbs.name: South East Face East Chimney Rock

content.description: Splitter finger and hand crack to limesone ledge (5.8) Star rating here only. 2nd pitch is 5.10X on chossy rock straight up from anchors or climb up and traverse right to finish on Red Headed Stranger 5.9R. Rap twice with one rope.

Chossy crack and face on East/ Northeast aspect of East (lower)Chimney rock. Once on the limestone ledge belay then climb up more chossy crack to a poorly protected (5.9R) traverse Right to a chimney and the Summit. Rap twice from the summit w/ one rope.
content.location: Chossy crack and face on East/Northeast aspect of East (lower)Chimney Rock.

content.description: Awesome old-school chimney pitch!  Quite clean varied route of all sizes, with a crux in a tight squeeze serious of moves protected by 1 bolt.
content.protection: Singles to 5" is a plenty good rack. Stoppers. 1 bolt? Fixed rap anchor at top off the SW side.
content.location: North side towards the West end, obvious slot system.   Rap route with 1 70m rope.

content.description: Chimney Rock is another easily recognized Sedona landmark and can be seen from nearly everywhere in town. This is the squared-off Castleton Spire looking rock that sticks up like a sore thumb off the ridgeline in the western part of Sedona. As you get closer, you will see that it is not even one formation, but two fin-like towers of squat rock. There are a a few established routes here, mostly in the hardman part of the spectrum, but the original line is cool.
